STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
September 9, 2020
Charles Rose
St Joseph County DHHS
692 East Main Street
Centreville, MI 49032
RE: License #: CP750201427
St Joseph County DHHS
692 East Main Street
Centreville, MI 49032
Dear Mr. Rose:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 9/2/20. Due
to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and Modified
Implementation Sustainability, and Exit Plan (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective
action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also
violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days
from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved; this includes identifying
behaviorally specific action steps.
o Repeat violations must include an explanation of why the previous
corrective action plan did not result in compliance.
 Individuals directly responsible for implementing the corrective action step for
each licensing statute and rule, Contract item, DHHS policy or MISEP section
citation, e.g. workers, supervisors, program managers, director, etc.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
implemented and completed.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved; this
includes identifying specific action steps for continuous monitoring.
o MiSACWIS users with access to the Book of Business, InfoView Reports
and the Monthly Child Welfare Management Report should incorporate the
use of these tools as well as other data management reports released by
the Department for continuous monitoring.
 Signature of the responsible party and date.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Claudia Triestram, the area manager at (616) 552-3662.
Sincerely,
Paul Fatato, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
322 E. Stockbridge Ave
Kalamazoo, MI 49001
(269) 251-2471
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP750201427
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services

Lansing, MI 48902

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12312 Foster parent training.
(4) At least 1 adult member of the household shall have training
in and maintain a current certification in first aid from the
American Heart Association or the American Red Cross or other
institution approved by the department.
One of six open foster home case files reviewed did not have documentation that the
CPR/first aid training was completed at the time the license was re-opened.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(g) A copy of the foster parent /agency agreement signed by
the foster parent and the borrowing agency.
One of three borrowed home case files reviewed did not have documentation that
the agreement was signed prior to the placement of the child in the home.
Placement took place on 12/17/19 and the agreement was signed on 1/30/20.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(3) An agency shall complete a special evaluation within 45
calendar days after receipt of the information. If additional time
is required, then the agency shall inform the foster parent, in
writing, of the basis for the extension and the expected length of
the extension. The total time for the completion of the
investigation shall not exceed 90 calendar days without written
approval from the chief administrator or his or her designee.
One of two special investigations reviewed did not have documentation in the 45-day
letter of the reasons the extension was needed.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
4

3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
DHHS Policy Medical Passport
FOM 801-page
11-13
Updated Medical Passport
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
Three of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that
the medical passports were completed as required. This involved two missing
medical passports and one that had a time frame exceeding the required three
months.
This is a repeat violation from the 2019 Renewal Licensing Study Report with
an approved CAP on 10/4/19 and the 2018 Interim Licensing Study Report with
an approved CAP on 11/16/18.
DHHS Policy Required Participation in Development – Foster Parent /
FOM 722-08C Caregiver / Parents and Youth over 14-years old.
page 2
The foster parent is required to sign each Parent Agency
Treatment Plan.
Parents and Youth over 14-Years Old The parents and a child
over 14 are required to sign each Parent Agency Treatment
Plan
CI 17-096 Treatment Plan Signature Timeframes and
Documentation Requirements
When the treatment plan is completed, signatures for all
appropriate case members must be obtained. Signatures from
all appropriate case members, including youth ages 14 and
older for foster care and youth ages 11 and older for juvenile
justice, should be obtained before the corresponding court
hearing. All treatment plans with a report date of August 1,
2017, or later must have signatures from all appropriate case
members within 30 days of the report date.
5

Eight of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have the appropriate
documentation of the required participation in the development of service plans
within the case file. This involved five missing parental signatures on five PATPs,
one missing youth signature on a PATP, two missing caregiver signatures on two
PATPs, and a youth and caregiver signature with no dates. There were also three
parent, two youth and two caregiver signatures that were beyond the 30-day time
frame.
One of one open independent living case files reviewed did not have the required
documentation of the youth participating in the development of the service plan. The
service plan was completed and approved on 6/25/20 and not signed by the youth
until 7/29/20.
This is a repeat violation from the 2019 Renewal Licensing Study Report with
an approved CAP on 10/4/19 and the 2018 Interim Licensing Study Report with
an approved CAP on 11/16/18.
DHHS Policy Caseworker contact child in out-of-home placement
FOM 722-06H
page 5
At least one contact each month must take place at the child’s
placement location.
One of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation of the
required monthly in placement visit by the caseworker. This involved one month with
no documentation that the caseworker was in the child’s placement for a visit.
Documentation did indicate that the worker met with the child but not at the
placement.
This is a repeat violation from the 2019 Renewal Licensing Study Report with
an approved CAP on 10/4/19.
DHHS Policy TIMELY ENTRY OF CASEWORKER CONTACTS
FOM 722-06H p
15
All face-to-face contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS within
five business days of the contact.
6

Seven of eight open foster care case files reviewed had documentation that all of the
face-to-face home visit contacts were not entered within the time frames as required.
This involved ninety-two of one hundred twenty-eight social work contacts reviewed
being timely for a seventy-two percentage.
One of one open independent living case files reviewed had documentation that all
of the face-to-face placement visit contacts were not entered within the required time
frames. This involved two of nine social work contacts being entered timely for a
twenty-two percentage.
DHHS Policy Family Team Meetings
722-06B - page
2-6
The following events shall trigger FTM for out of home cases:
• Case service plan development,
• placement preservation/disruption: At least three business
days prior to a planned change of placement or no later than
three business days after an unplanned placement change.
Note: Planned and unplanned placement changes include
reunification, placement in a residential setting, step-down from
a residential or hospital setting, return from AWOLP, or request
for change in foster home/relative placements.
Two of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have all of the required
Family Team Meetings documented in the case file. This involved a missing FTM for
a youth who went AWOL and a missing FTM for a case service plan development.
This is a repeat violation from the 2019 Renewal Licensing Study Report with
an approved CAP on 10/4/19 and the 2018 Interim Licensing Study Report with
an approved CAP on 11/16/18. Because of the continued positive improvement
with this licensing rule (five issues last inspection to two this inspection), they
can continue to use and submit for this CAP the aspects of their past CAP if
they believe it will continue to help with improved compliance.
DHHS Policy The DHHS-1295, Young Adult Monthly Visit Report The
FOM 722-16 – DHHS-1295
page 11
Young Adult Monthly Visit Report must be completed with the
youth during each home visit. A copy must be given to the youth
and the original placed in the case file.
One of one open independent living case file reviewed did not have documentation
that the required DHHS-1295 was completed for two months.
7

DHHS Policy DHHS-69 Action Summary
FOM 722-09C –
page 1-2
The Foster Care/Juvenile Justice (FC/JJ) Action Summary,
DHHS-69 (RFF 69), is used whenever there is “action” on a
case.
All foster care cases where there is:
1. A replacement.
One of one open independent living case file reviewed that involved a replacement
had the DHHS-69 completed but the effective date was 5/14/20 and the form was
not completed until 7/16/20 which is beyond the required time frame.
This is a repeat violation from the 2019 Renewal Licensing Study Report with
an approved CAP on 10/4/19 and the 2018 Interim Licensing Study Report with
an approved CAP on 11/16/18. Because of the continued positive improvement
with this licensing rule (two issues last inspection to one this inspection), they
can continue to use and submit for this CAP the aspects of their past CAP if
they believe it will continue to help with improved compliance.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 One of the enrolled homes had several issues that resulted in a delay in the
licensing process. It was discussed with the agency that there was a possible
“personality conflict” between the licensing worker and the foster parents. it
was suggested that the agency develop a system to ensure that if this occurs
in the future, they have a process to identify and resolve the issue.
 There was a significant amount of documentation that was not uploaded into
the MiSACWIS system. We discussed the importance of the development of
a process to resolve this issue given the current situation with the COVID-19
limitations.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The agency was not investigated this licensing period for alleged noncompliance
with Licensing Rules, ISEP, or DHHS Policies.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan for their 2019
Renewal inspection during this licensing period. Compliance with the CAP was
8

achieved unless noted above as a repeat violation.
Staff Interviews:
Several different levels of staff were interviewed, and all report a strong belief in
providing “best practice” to their families. The Case Managers report a belief that they
are supported by administration but also indicated hoping to have more time in the
office to complete tasks that cannot be completed at home. The supervisors report
being supported by administration and believe they are coping with the COVIFD-19
restrictions as best as can be expected.
VII. DCWL FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety alerts or concerns during this review period. The field analyst
interviewed six caregivers and six children and reported that all indicated satisfaction
with the agency.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or policy. Upon receipt
of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue
on a regular license.
9/4/2020
________________________________________
Paul Fatato Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
September 9, 2020
________________________________________
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
9
